Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Plant traits as indicators of ecological restoration effectiveness in tropical landscapes
Award.AbstractNarration:
The majority of tropical forests are regenerating following human disturbance. Some landscapes are so highly degraded that active restoration, such as direct tree planting, is necessary to facilitate forest recovery. In tropical forests requiring active management interventions, a wide range of restoration techniques have been employed to assist forest recovery at various stages of re-growth, although it is not clear how to best select tree species for restoration projects, especially given ongoing changes to the environment. This graduate student project seeks to determine how above- and below-ground plant traits influence the survival and growth of planted trees, to determine if plant traits can be used to efficiently and inexpensively select the best tree species for restoration of Costa Rican tropical dry forests (TDF). These forests are highly endangered, cover an estimated 42% of tropical land area, and are understudied compared to their wetter counterparts. Results from this research have the potential to greatly advance ecological restoration theory, and to aid in the restoration of tropical dry forests, especially those facing significant drought stress due to ongoing environmental change.

This project takes a functional trait-based approach to experimentally test the efficiency of using plant traits to select tree species for a large-scale TDF restoration project. Field based quantification of above- and belowground plant traits, as well as genetic analyses of fungal communities associating with plant roots, will be combined with tree seedling growth data to determine the extent to which above- and belowground traits can be used to predict plant performance in a restoration setting. A 6-hectare restoration experiment will be used to determine if species' trait syndromes, grouped by resource acquisition strategies, predict the performance of tree species along successional trajectories. In addition to conducting these projects, the researchers will engage the local conservation, forestry, and farming community in a workshop on TDF adaptive management strategies. These projects will also give undergraduate students the opportunity to conduct independent research projects in collaboration with the researchers. All of this research will be conducted in direct collaboration with TDF restoration practitioners at Horizontes Experimental Forest Station, part of the Guanacaste Conservation Area in Northwestern Costa Rica.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Tropical forests have been extensively deforested and degraded due to anthropogenic activities. To counteract these impacts active management interventions such as tree planting are necessary to catalyze forest regeneration in many regions. The overall goal of our project was to investigate how plant functional traits, standardized characteristic that infer how plants use and acquire resources, influence the growth and survival of tropical dry forest trees in restoration projects. Tropical dry forests and have been extensively deforested worldwide and their restoration remains understudied compared to tropical wet forests. To accomplish our goals we designed and implemented two large-scale active restoration experiments on a degraded former pasture in tropical dry forest in northwestern Costa Rica. This work trained a doctoral candidate and two undergraduate students in the development and implementation of tropical ecology research.

We implemented our experiments to catalyze tropical dry forest regeneration on Vertisols, soils with shrink-swell cycles that have been heavily degraded in this region. Our results demonstrate that ecophysiological (photosynthetic and water-use) functional traits are highly predictive of tropical dry forest tree survival and growth at early- and mid-successional stages. On way in which we determined this was by developing a novel technique to rapidly quantify plant water-use strategies using stable isotopes. These results highlight the importance of plant water-use and photosynthetic strategies in driving successional dynamics in tropical dry forests. We also found that considering these traits when designing restorations improves project outcomes. Overall, our findings are also consistent with growing support for the understanding that 'soft', or easy to measure, leaf traits are poor predictors of tree performance, and our work shows that certain ecophysiological traits are highly predictive of tree demographic rates in tropical dry forests. Last, our findings are the first to indicate that it is difficult but possible to restore tropical dry forest on degraded Vertisol soils and highlights that restoration experiments implemented in collaboration with restoration practitioners result in the development of management best practices that improve tropical forest restoration outcomes.
